div.head: Summary
div.p: In this sūtra, the goddess Tārā warns the gods of the desire realm about the miseries of saṃsāra and offers a pithy Dharma teaching to free them from it. Tārā begins by vividly portraying the various kinds of suffering endured by beings in each of the six realms of saṃsāra and then points out the futility of reciting mantras without maintaining pure conduct. She goes on to encourage the listeners to engage in virtue, which puts an end to saṃsāra, and bestows on them an incantation (dhāraṇī) that will help practitioners to achieve this goal. The gods then commend Tārā for her instruction, praise her qualities, and request her divine protection. Finally, the Buddha enjoins his audience to read, write, recite, and understand Tārā’s teaching and to explain it to others.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Translated by Lhasey Lotsawa Translations and Publications under the guidance of Phakchok Rinpoche. The translation and introduction were produced by Stefan Mang and Peter Woods with the kind assistance of David Higgins. The translation and introduction were edited by Oriane Lavolé and Laura Goetz.

While the Buddha is dwelling on top of Mount Meru in the desire realm, along with the goddess Tārā and an assembly of gods, Tārā vividly warns the divine gathering about the various kinds of suffering endured by beings in each of the six realms of saṃsāra. She emphasizes that the fates of each of these kinds of beings are the result of negative actions and that virtuous conduct is the only way to avoid and alleviate such suffering. Tārā goes on to describe the path to liberation using a series of evocative metaphors, and then offers an incantation (dhāraṇī) to help practitioners achieve liberation from saṃsāra. The gods respond to Tārā’s words by extolling her myriad qualities, in particular her ability to protect beings from the eight great dangers. Finally, the Buddha enjoins his audience to read, write, recite, and understand Tārā’s teaching and to explain it to others. In sum, this sūtra emphasizes the benefits of reciting sacred formulae or mantras and reiterates Tārā’s popular role as a protectress who swiftly aids those in need whenever called upon.

The sūtra can be divided into three sections: (1) a concise teaching given by Tārā to the gods of the desire realm on the suffering of saṃsāra and the Dharma practice that alleviates it; (2) an incantation that will help practitioners to achieve this goal; Parts of this incantation are also found in other incantations to Tārā such as the Sādhanamālā mantra of Vajratārā (Bhattacharyya 1925, p. 178) and The Incantation of Tārā (Toh 729, sgrol ma’i gzungs), to give only two examples. and (3) a praise to Tārā offered by the assembled gods. In the third section, the gods praise Tārā as one who displays the gesture of protection For various iconographic descriptions of Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Great Dangers, see for example Shin 2010, pp. 20–22 and Shaw 2006, pp. 319–322. and request Tārā to give protection against the eight great dangers, which the sūtra then lists as lions, elephants, fire, snakes, robbers, waters, infectious diseases, and demons. The only difference between this list and the most common list of eight great dangers is that this list includes infectious diseases instead of imprisonment. These verses reveal how Tārā protects beings from the eight great dangers, which gives the sūtra its title. The Kangyur manuscripts suggest that the Sanskrit title of this text was *Ārya­tārāṣṭa­ghoretāsvī­sūtra or a variant thereof. We have followed the Tōhoku catalogue, amending the title to *Ārya­tārāṣṭa­ghora­tāraṇī­sūtra. It is worthwhile to note that the Sanskrit term *aṣṭaghora appears to be a unique way to refer to the eight great dangers. The commonly used Sanskrit term is aṣṭamahābhaya. Both terms are very similar in meaning and both can be translated into Tibetan as ’jigs pa [chen po] brgyad.

In the Degé Kangyur, this sūtra is part of a cycle of eight Kriyātantra (bya rgyud) texts (Toh 724–731) dedicated to the goddess Tārā. There is to our knowledge no extant Sanskrit version of this sūtra. It is not found in the Denkarma (ldan dkar ma) or Phangthangma (’phang thang ma) Tibetan imperial translation catalogues. There is also no Chinese version recorded the Taishō Buddhist Canon. The colophon names no translator or editor.The text is found in Kangyur collections of the Tshalpa (tshal pa) group, such as the Degé, Lhasa, Lithang, and Choné Kangyurs. However, it is not found in any of the Thempangma (them spangs ma) group or the Ladakh/Mustang Kangyur collections. It is also not found in the Dunhuang collections. All this suggests a relatively late date of composition and translation (perhaps not before the eleventh century).

The text has been previously introduced and translated into English by Martin Willson. See Willson 1996, pp. 87–93. Willson’s translation is based on the Peking edition of the sūtra. This English translation is based on the Tibetan version in the Degé Kangyur collection, in consultation with the Lhasa edition and the variant readings recorded in the Comparative Edition (dpe bsdur ma) Kangyur.

div.head: The Translation
The Noble Sūtra
Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Great Dangers

lg.l: Homage to the Three Jewels.
Homage to the venerable lady Tārā.
Homage to the Blessed Śākyamuni.

div.p: Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was dwelling in the realm of gods atop Mount Meru. At that time, the goddess Tārā, who was in the assembly, spoke the following:

lg.l: “Now that you have reached this jewel-like higher realm,
You should understand actions and their results:
Adhere to the good and abandon the bad,
For those who engage in evil actions
Will plunge downward when they pass from this world.
“Animals, dumb and stupid, eat one another,
Climbing and descending, up and down, on an abysmal path of toil.
Terrified and afraid, trembling in panic,
Their dread-filled sufferings defy imagination.
“Pretas hunger and thirst, their bodies deformed.
Even if food and drink does appear, it is guarded by others,
And even if consumed by some, it turns to fire and swords.
Their suffering from hunger and thirst defies imagination.
“Those beings who are born in the hell realms
Are led by Yama’s henchmen against their will.
Burned and boiled, they are sliced asunder by swords;
Their suffering from heat and cold is unendurable.
“Thus, those who commit evil deeds in this life
Only compound the damage they inflict on themselves.
They will be tormented by intense suffering for many eons,
With no opportunity to escape or the possibility to bear it.
“Keep this clearly in mind, and know these as the fruits of such actions.
Otherwise you will sow the seeds of your own unbearable suffering and lament.
Even others will be frightened by the terrible din of your agonized screams,
For these kinds of sufferings are beyond imagination!
“Whoever understands such grave misfortunes
Will abandon the causes of the three lower realms.
Wherever there are evil deeds, subtle or coarse,
Act swiftly by way of body, speech, and mind.
“You will be happy and of help to all beings.
You will give up attachment, aversion, and ignorance and rely upon the root of compassion.
You will practice virtue, striving avidly with all three doors—

Endeavor, then, in this most profound quintessence! Quintessence (hṛdaya, snying po) here refers to an incantation (dhāraṇī, gzungs) that is considered to encapsulate the essence of a deity, in this case Tārā, and represents an essential method for attaining a supernatural result (Sánchez 2011, p. 37).
“The fruit of a flower taken by frost,
Although cultivated, will produce no sprouts.
Likewise, those consumed by doubts who transgress their vows
May practice the most profound of vidyāmantras,
Thinking, ‘Blessings will come,’ but this is impossible—
Their efforts amount to meaningless exhaustion.
“Their vidyāmantras are like the prattle of common folk,
Their meditations like the musings of a child.
But if people without fault practice vidyāmantras,
They will swiftly accomplish whatever they desire.
“Take these examples: The seed of the banyan tree,
Though tiny, will grow as much as a league across in seven months
When well moistened with water and manure.
If even external matter grows like this,
Why speak of cultivating awareness with awareness?
The growth of inner luminosity is beyond measure.
“If one relies on a chief merchant who knows the way
And sets out on the seas in an excellent ship,
One will find whatever riches are desired
And sail smoothly back to one’s home.
“If one relies on love, compassion, joy, and equanimity This is a reference to the four immeasurables (caturapramāṇa, tshad med bzhi).
And practices virtue endowed with the mind of awakening,
One will set out on the path of true perfection
And definitely reach the land of wisdom.
“If an arrow has been loosed from a person’s fingers,
It has certainly been shot, even if one thinks otherwise.
And if a person realizes all goals, the nature of reality,
The other shore has certainly been reached, even if one thinks otherwise.
“Once the aspects of conduct are naturally accomplished,
The fruit of buddhahood will undoubtedly be won.
When the pristine nature of reality is realized,
There is no self, no life force or termination of life force,
No karma, and no karmic ripening.
The extremes are abandoned, and one is liberated.
“In order for you to realize that goal,
Devotedly recite this quintessence as I proclaim it.
If you do, the evil deeds of three incalculable eons will be eradicated,
All the sufferings of the three lower realms and saṃsāra will be washed away,
And the obscurations will be cleared away.
This meaningful quintessence is as follows:

p.mantra: oṁ bodhisattvā mahāsattvā, goddess, please protect us!
p.note: The first part of this incantation (dhāraṇī) is an homage to Tārā. Since the Tibetan translator(s) chose to render this part into Tibetan, it is also translated into English here.

p.mantra: oṁ nama āryāvalokiteśvarāya bodhi­sattvāya mahā­sattvāya mahā­kāruṇikāya |
p.note: The second part of this incantation presents a standard homage to Avalokiteśvara. We have amended namo to nama following the homage as given in the Vajra­tārā­sādhanas in the Sādhana­mālā (see e.g. Bhattacharyya 1925, p. 178) and The Incantation of Tārā. A tentative translation of it is as follows: “ oṁ! Homage to Noble Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva mahāsattva, the great compassionate one!”
Tadyathā, literally “it is like this,” is a stock phrase used indicate the beginning of the actual mantra that follows.

p.mantra: oṁ tāre tuttāre ture sarva­duṣṭān praduṣṭān mama kṛte jambhaya stambhaya mohaya bandhaya hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā |
p.note: The third part this incantation is a request to Tārā to dispel obstacles. This part is found as an independent incantation in, for example, the Sādhanamālā as the mantra of Vajratārā (Bhattacharyya 1925, p. 178), The Incantation of Tārā, and elsewhere (Beyer 1978, pp. 280–281). A tentative translation of it is as follows: “It is like this: oṁ! Deliverer! Savior! Swift One! Crush, suppress, confound, restrain all the wrong and evil beings for me! hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā!”

p.mantra: nama āryāvalobhayā narā bodhisattvā mahā­sattvāni adhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhite mama sarva­karmāvaraṇa svabhāva­śuddhe viśuddhe śodhaya viśodhaya hūṁ phaṭ svāhā |
p.note: The fourth part of this incantation is a request to Tārā to purify one’s obscurations. We have amended the first two beginning syllables mama to nama following the incantation as given in Butön’s Incantation Collection (gzungs bsdus) in his Collected Works (gsung ’bum). The remaining part of the incantation appears to be corrupted. The letters bha and ka are very similar and often confused in old Newar and other scripts, so āryāvalobha- probably was originally āryāvaloka-. This is probably a reference to Āryāvalokiteśvara, whose name might have been followed by the standard bhodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ. A tentative translation is as follows: “Homage to you, [Tārā,] empowered with the blessing of Noble Avalokita, the great bodhisattva mahāsattva! Purify, completely purify, cleanse, and completely cleanse all my karmic obscurations! hūṁ phaṭ svāhā !”

div.p: Then the beings praised the goddess who was herself the embodiment of buddhahood: This is a tentative rendering of the phrase: de nas sangs rgyas nyid kyis su/ /lha mo nyid la rab tu bstod.

lg.l: “Lady who acts with immense compassion for the good of beings—
You have all the major and minor marks and are bedecked with precious jewels.
You smile in a most ravishing way with a laughing countenance.

Your eyes The Tibetan text refers the sense organs of Tārā as spheres or bases (skye mched, āyatana). Our translation omits these references in order to retain the poetic quality of the stanza. are like flax blossoms.A type of flax flower (atasī, zar ma).

“Your ears are like blossoming trumpet flowers. Trumpet flowers here translates ug cos, which appears to be a spelling variant of ug chos. Dan Martin identifies the ug chos flower as Incarvillea compacta maxim, an herb with pink trumpet shaped flowers used in Tibetan medicine (Martin 2003).
Your nose is like an utpala lotus bud.

Your mouth is like a mallow in full bloom,Mallow here translates ha lo, which according to Dan Martin belongs to the lcam pa flower family, a type of malva flower (Martin 2003). The flower is also used in Tibetan medicine. It appears that the Tibetan translator(s) rendered the names of original, possibly Indic, flowers with the names of flowers used in Tibetan medicine that are similar in appearance to their Indic counterparts.
Your body is that of a well-endowed maiden, appearing in various guises.
“Your speech is that of a kalaviṅka bird, proclaiming the Dharma.
Your heart, filled with compassion, guards all beings with love.
Your left hand holds a lotus, for you are unstained by saṃsāra’s flaws.
Your right hand grants protection to all beings to help fulfill their aims.
“You are seated on the sun and moon of method and wisdom.
Venerable lady Tārā, we take refuge in you!
Protect us from the great abyss of saṃsāra!
“Oh, how we circle in any of the six transmigrations!
May you secure us with your noose of great compassion.
Oh, how we stray into the three lower realms!
May you put us on the path from which we will not stray.
“Oh, how we are born into families with wrong views!
Please introduce us to a teacher who possesses the mind of awakening.
Oh, how we would otherwise meet with false friends!
“To you who protects from the eight dangers—
Lions, elephants, fire, snakes,
Robbers, waters, infectious diseases, and demons—
We pay homage!
In this life and in those to come,
Please protect us from these eight great dangers!
“Until we have reached our goal, the other shore,
May we make the ten perfections of generosity, moral conduct,
Patience, diligence, concentration, insight,
Method, aspiration, strength, and wisdom
Our inseparable allies!

div.p: The Buddha then replied, “Sons and daughters of noble family, you should write down this teaching, read it, recite it, understand it, correctly bring it to mind, and explain it extensively to others.”
At this point, the whole assembly rejoiced and offered praise.
div.trailer: This completes The Sūtra “Venerable Lady Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Great Dangers.” The title listed here differs from the title given on the first page as “Noble” (’phags ma) is missing. Instead, “Venerable Lady” (rje btsun ma) is added. The Comparative Edition notes that the Lithang and Choné versions add yang zhus ste/te skar to the end of the colophon (p. 601). The phrase could be rendered as “re-edited and sorted.”

gloss.term: This word has a wide semantic range and thus could likewise be translated as knowledge, learning, insight, consciousness, or cognition. We felt that rendering rig pa here as “awareness” opens the English translation to a variety of possible interpretations.
A fast-growing fig tree that can quickly become a large tree. It features prominently in Indian stories and myths.
A class of flesh-eating and shape-shifting demons.

Listed in Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Great Dangers as lions, elephants, fire, snakes, robbers, waters, infectious diseases, and demons. A more common enumneration gives “imprisonment” rather than “infectious diseases.”

In Buddhist literature refers to a mythical bird with the head of a human and the body of a bird. The kalaviṅka’s call is said to be far more beautiful than that of all other birds and so compelling that it could be heard even before the bird has hatched. The call of the kalaviṅka is also used as an analogy to describe the voice of the Buddha.
A measure of distance. The exact value is disputed and varies in different sources from 1–40 km.
A flower belonging to the lcam pa family, a type of malva flower used in Tibetan medicine.

The trainings of the bodhisattva path. Most commonly listed as six: generosity, moral conduct, patience, diligence, concentration, and insight. Sometimes, such as in this text, an additional four are added: method, aspiration, strength, and wisdom.
Incarvillea compacta maxim, an herb with pink trumpet-shaped flowers used in Tibetan medicine.
A sacred utterance or spell made for the purpose of attaining either worldly or transcendent benefits.
The lord of death, who judges the dead and rules over the hells.
realm of gods atop Mount Meru
ri rab kyi steng lha’i gnas

Likely refers to the Heaven of the Thirty-Three (Trāyastriṃśa, sum cu rtsa gsum), the second heaven of the desire realm situated on the summit of Mount Meru and presided over by thirty-three gods, of whom Śakra is the chief.
A goddess (lit. “Savior”) known for giving protection. She is variously presented in Buddhist literature as a great bodhisattva or a fully awakened buddha.
A class of beings who, in the Buddhist tradition, are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
